title: Cold Weather Cattle Management Webinar - March 12 2019

tasks.task: Outline the physical tasks related to body condition scoring and managing bulls during winter.
subtasks: Assessing cow and bull body condition through visual inspection (ribs, spine, shape between hooks and pins).
Tracking body condition scores to maintain optimal levels (5-7 at calving) and prevent weight loss.
Ensuring bull semen quality by maintaining appropriate body condition (4-7 at breeding time) and monitoring for frostbite.

tasks.task: Explain the impact of cold weather on calves and the importance of intervention.
subtasks: Recognizing cold-stressed calves through behavior changes (standing alone, hunched, dry udders, vocalizing).
Implementing intervention strategies (bedding, windbreaks, supplemental warmth, colostrum administration).
Enhancing calf survival rates by maintaining thermal comfort and energy reserves.

tasks.task: Discuss agricultural management practices to adapt to limited hay supply.
subtasks: Adjusting feeding strategies (using grains, by-products, supplementation) to stretch hay reserves.
Monitoring pasture readiness for grazing (plant development, growing degree days) and planning early utilization.
Implementing rotational grazing to sustain pasture productivity and reduce overgrazing.

tasks.task: Address environmental stewardship in grazing management during spring transitions.
subtasks: Evaluating pasture health and potential risks (drought impacts, invasive species) before turnout.
Considering plot-specific factors (riparian areas, flood risks) when planning early grazing rotations.

tasks.task: Body Condition Scoring and Bull Management
subtasks: Explain the three-step body condition scoring system for cattle (ribs, spine, shape between hooks/pins).
Discuss the importance of maintaining body condition scores (5-7) at calving to ensure productivity and calf health.
Highlight the effect of body condition on energy reserves and reproductive performance (semen quality, conception rates).
Identify behavioral signs of cold-stressed calves (isolated standing, hunched posture, dry udder, vocalization).
Outline intervention methods: proper bedding, windbreaks, use of warm water baths, and colostrum supplementation.
Emphasize the critical role of colostrum in severely hypothermic calves for energy and immune support.
Evaluate alternative forages (grain, by-products) and their impact on cattle nutrition.
Implement feeding schedules that consider cattle energy needs (e.g., late afternoon feeding) and minimize waste (ventilated feeders).
Consider supplementing poor-quality forages with high-protein by-products (e.g., wheat middlings, distiller's grains).
Assess the timing of pasture turnout based on plant development stages (three-leaf for introduced grasses, three-and-a-half for bromes).
Plan rotational grazing to match pasture readiness with cattle needs, considering early spring growth dynamics.
Prepare for potential challenges (invasive species, drought stress) in native pastures and adjust management accordingly.
